reviewText: Learn CPR to leave the planet"Pretty cool F2P Scifi 3D Adventure on a extraterrestial station. It has nice cellshade graphics and a relaxing soundtrack. Main purpose is some medical education for CPR (reanimation). There are 4 chapters and many floppy shaped collectibles to find. Pickup tools like screwdriver and crowbar to open vents and extend your PDA with extra battery life to hack into electronic doorlocks. It's rather minor challenging but makes quite fun to solve the puzzles."
voteText: 17 of 18 people (94%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You're stuck on a base on Mars and you're in the middle of a storm. Alone, you have to find your team and bring what they need... but before doing that, you'll have to pass a course about CPR, never realising that you'll be using these skills sooner than later.

For a free game, I must say that I'm impressed by the quality of it. I'm maybe biased because I test a lot of serious games. Relive is belonging to this category: learning by having fun. It's not like I'll do CPR in real life but I know at least some of the basics.

The graphics are looking like a Telltale game (The Wolf Among Us or The Walking Dead) but contrary to the two I've mentionned, you're not really making any choices (apart when you need to pass the CPR test and when you perform the trick). You have to unlock doors, crawl in vents, move crates, realign antennas.... In other words, the gameplay is varied, which is a good thing, though the CPR focus is less the spotlight. The fact that you can find secrets is also a nice distraction.

However, you can have good graphics and suffer from bugs. I've been stuck between a door and a wall and a desk, I've jumped through the wall. Or I fell from the map in the hangar. And when you know that you can't save in the level (your progression is saved at the end of the level), it's kinda annoying.

Also, while I'm glad that they mapped the arrows to move, I've still a problem with WASD, used in the hacking minigames. You can't change the layout of that. So, instead of having natural movements, W, which is to go up, is under the S which is to go down, like A is on the left but a line above. You understood: I've an AZERTY keyboard. If the devs could map ZQSD or the arrows for the minigame, I'll be much faster to solve them.

True, I would have preferred to have it also in French, because not everyone is fluent in English (or in Italian). But I don't mind that: you can see the gesture, which is important.

Also, you don't need to play the four chapters for learning about CPR and be aware of that, you can launch a training session. And you can also compete if you have a Kinect to practice IRL!

Since they added a voice-over, the game is now less silent: the voice acting is decent - I was disappointed by the AI that is nearly without emotion despite the faces they're doing. However, the rest can pass.

So, yeah, test it, it's free. But I'm surely recommending it!
voteText: 19 of 25 people (76%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is simply fantastic, and I urge every gamer to try this out at some point.

Relive has been made to try and teach as many people as possible CPR in order to save as many lives as possible. And amazingly, the game is completely free so they can reach a much larger audience. I believe those facts alone make this game worth a try.

There's a story mode, training mode and a tournament mode (which needs a Kinect). The story mode includes CPR without being intrusive, and looks like it's good fun to play through while also teaching people how important learning CPR can be. The training mode will show you through hands-only CPR and how it should be correctly performed, as well as with a defibrillator (AED). The tournament mode plays you against friends and family while using a Kinect, to see who can perform the best CPR, and will score each persons attempt.

The game seems to play smoothly on Windows 10, didn't have any crash issues and I haven't yet seen any bugs/glitches.
The only suggestion I could make is that they add some kind of charity link to the description and in-game, that would help fund research for Cardiac Arrests (such as The British Heart Foundation).

If you'd like to see all this for yourself, check here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0zFLObe43PE
voteText: 26 of 38 people (68%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This was an okay title, but for the purpose it was designed for, I would say it was even above average. Plus, free to play, so there is that.

So, how do you design an informal CPR training class in the form of a video game. Easy....have a research station of Mars that suddenly faces disaster, and you have to save your fellow researchers using the CPR skills you learn in the game. Which actually works quite well. While this game is no masterpiece, I felt it did a good job of presenting a CPR lesson in an approachable way.

As far as the game itself, it is a bit cel shade and a bit Unity engine, with essentially point and click puzzles (and a couple stack stuff to get to other stuff puzzles thrown in ).

...and that is pretty much it. I took my time and probably played for about an hour and a half while also watching sports, lol.

I will leave this unrated but recommend that you at least check it out. It's free, it's somewhat informative, and is a decent attempt at making education fun.

Cheers!

reviewText:
This game has almost no sound effects - no voice acting, no footstep sounds, no breathing sounds, and something that should be really loud at the end of the game (a huge EMP ♥♥♥♥storm goes off that literally covers atleast 20% of mars surface) makes no sound either. The only real sound in the game is the annoying as ♥♥♥♥ soundtrack that repeats constantly, that literally gave me a headache.

None of the first person animations you see in the trailer are an actual thing, there is almost no dynamic gameplay in this game at all

Controls are clunky - you can press the throw button after picking up and object (crucial to some very tedious stuff in the game) and you will ♥♥♥♥ up because your character decided not to throw it that particular time you pressed the button. Your character moves floaty as ♥♥♥♥.

In my opinion the secrets in this game are lame and the puzzles aren't fun either. You don't feel intelligent to solve any of these puzzles and they are all really nobrainers.

game is pretty buggy, I managed to phase through alot of objects and at one point got stuck behind a door - to finally wiggle my way out and teleport through the wall behind me to safety after 3 minutes

If you want to learn about CPR don't play this, the games idea of you doing CPR to save people is doing multiple choice after being given the answers literally two times over where you have to sit through the horrible animation

is a real shame, game has an interesting setting and theme but doesn't try at all to immerse you or make you give a ♥♥♥♥ about anything that is happening.

atleast it's better than gone home

P.S don't do the tutorial mission you literally have to do it in the main game midway through anyway
voteText: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to learn basic CPR and save people from a swarm of crazed AI nanobots? Well then this might just be the game for you.

First off this game is free. So there is no excuse not to give it a go. It’s not all that long clocking in at around 2 hours and that includes collecting all the secrets. That being said I had a great time with this game.

The way in which it teaches you CPR is a little contrived but I learned a couple things and had fun doing it. You take the role of a scientist trapped on Mars. Your home is surrounded by a swarm of malevolent AI controlled nanobots hell bent on destroying all that lay in their path. It is up to you to save the day and transport the knowledge mankind needs to defeat the AI whilst saving as many people as you can along the way.

The controls are pretty good, the game whilst not graphically stunning has a very nice art style to it. I adored the computer mascot designs; they were adorable and added to the charm of the game, especially the medical one. The story is well written for such a short piece and portrays a lot of world building and character depth. I thoroughly enjoyed my jaunt through the base and would gladly return to learn more about everything that went on behind the scenes and how hopefully mankind will retake Mars.

I recommend this to anyone that has a couple hours to spare and just want a nice short adventure whilst simultaneously learning very VERY basic skills that may help you save a life someday. And as I mentioned its free so no reason not to.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
Joke Review:  Welcome to the male-on-male sexual harassment simulator.  The only game where you get to kiss men while they're passed out and grope their boobies while claiming you're giving them CPR.

Real Review:  Well, I thought to give this game a try.   It' not too bad, but it does not live-up to the feeling of panic, survival, horror, and possible combat that the trailer hints at which makes you think it'll be pretty long with a pretty good story....not quite.

You play the game as ERROR 404 (according to your apartment door) and get a message from your boss.  Lug around a Companion Cube you can't use for anything box of plot device data you cannot access throughout the base.   You are forced to learn CPR to continue through the base before putting it into practice one time.  The game's narrative isn't much and the dialogue seems to be a little wordy for an emergency situation through 4 chapters you'll finish in 1-2 hours.  (My log says 4-5 hours due to replaying to find an achievement)

Breakdown:

Chapter 1:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-tGL-buZ94Y
Wake up, pack your box, run away.  (Or as the video says... Get your sh*t together!")

Chapter 2:  Mandatory CPR lesson after meticulous running around and puzzle solving.  (This will be your longest chapter
date:
hands-down)

Chapter 3:  Cube physics that will make you wonder why they companion cube logic isn't good and why you're falling through boxes you're climbing.  Put your CPR into action.

Chapter 4:  Pack the ship
hoursPlayed:
escape.




Pros:
A noble cause for the purpose of CPR.
Run-around adventure.  (if you like that sort of thing)
Puzzles here and there along the way.
Decent usage of 3D models. (They look like they came out of Borderlands)
Free.
Achievements.

Cons:
A plot that isn't all that good.
Misleading trailer.
Although human models are decent

reviewText: Relive is a pretty decent adventure game, and I had fun playing it. While the game itself is short the cel-shaded environments look pretty neat, and the story held my attention. The game benefits from its mysterious atmosphere, and at some moments could be downright eerie. Overall there are four levels, a few simple puzzles, a handful of collectibles to find on each level and a theme centered around learning CPR. Again, the game itself is a very simple indie game.\n\nI felt the game is decent enough for a positive review, and I myself enjoyed it more than I should have. I recommend it to anyone who is a fan of indie adventure games, has an hour to spare, or the odd person who wants to play a game specifically that will teach them the basics of CPR.

reviewText:
Check out my gameplay:

https://youtu.be/iQbj04AtZ8k

Initial Impressions:

+ve:
It's free.
It's helping you learn how to react in emergency situations as well as learning CPR.
The developers have your health in mind – although don’t run in an emergency!!!!
For a game that you pay absolutely nothing for, it's a great time killer.
I have seen games that you have to pay for that follow a similar style to this, the only thing better was the in those games was the graphics, they were not worth it.   The graphics on this are pretty good, I expected A LOT worse.
No hidden charges - Maybe they should have had unlockable items/character upgrades or something along those lines and the money would go to research into heart care or something a long those line?  I personally would pay a couple of quid for this game and know the money was going to a good cause.  A thought for the developers next time?
Would be a great learning tool for young children!  If you are a teacher you could maybe incorporate some of this game into a lesson?
May even be fun in the workplace, the CPR tournament mode, for example!   This would be a great addition to a medical training course, and probably a laugh for all the people involved.  In this sense the game has endless possibilities.

-ves
gets boring quickly, although that may just be me, as I am impatient.

Overall, there isn’t a lot to complain about.  I think the developers should be proud of their achievement and the cause that they are promoting through the game!  If any of the developers read this, well done folks!!

reviewText:
Intent may be good, but it would have been more appealling with a better gameplay...

I don't care about the graphics, the sounds, the story and nearly all the rest. I cared about how the CPR thing was given in it and how the levels are finished.

And so what made me give a bad rating:
- Code on first story level... took me 25 minutes to complete the level, but maybe I was an idiot... ?
- Trash crates on second story level... took me 55 minutes (!) to complete it because... well, because our character can't make difference between a trash crate and a supply crate by looking... he's an idiot.
Made a second go, a commenter (Vic=HCK=) gave me the way to check the crates... and I'm against this method. You don't put completely different things in the same looking crates! In real world, if we where to put used medical supplies (I'm thinking about syringes) in the same looking crates that the unused and clean ones in the same spot, in a hospital or medical facility...
- Third story level badly made... if you are a little slow poke, these dudes would be dead. It took me more than 5 minutes to figure out how to unlock the door and I could have taken all the time in the world.
- For rescue, you need to choose the good answers, and you watch your guy doing it. Well, couldn't it be better? Easy yes! COULD. BE. BETTER. THAN. THIS! At least make the player have some WASD and space inputs! A hacking gameplay has been made, why not a CPR? (without the kinect, which I don't have and don't want to buy for now...)

1.6 hours, 10 minutes of excitement, 10 minutes of curiousity around background story/set atmosphere and the CPR introduction, rest is only boredom and keep on going" mode because of the higher points. Even a real CPR class may be funnier and more interesting than this. Even if the funny side isn't intended and wanted."

reviewText:
Long story short, it sucks.

Long story long, Relive is one of the most fascinating failures I've seen on the Steam free market. I've never seen a game set out for one, simple, little task and not only divert its focus from that task, but sucks massive balls while doing so.

It's a game about CPR! So make a game about CPR!

Seriously, the training session is completely unncessary. It's literally a sequence cut out from Chapter 2, where all you do is just get told about the steps for CPR and watch some awkward animations of the character doing CPR. No interaction. Just questions and answers. I remember when I learned CPR, I had to actually perform it on a dummy. Isn't there any way it could've at least made a mini game out of it?

And what's up with the story mode? It's awkwardly and slowly paced, with sluggish controls and incredibly pace-lengthening tasks that are so boring I started counting how many character's voices were generated by a computer. Basically, it's all the robots, although I'd guess that a couple of the humans act just as much like the robots in this game.

Basically, there's a big storm in Mars, you have to get out, but before you do you have to calmly walk through different corridors and single-handedly equip and prepare a ship for take off, so some lazy-a** crew can get to safety. Isn't it their job to prepare the ship? I was busy saving their crew's lives in the previous level, and also carried their box with data cores inside for them!

The sound is awful in this too... well, besides the voice-acting. There's no sound effects. For anything. No footsteps. No Mars-storm sounds. No crowbar-hitting-steel sounds. Just nothing. And it's really... really... boring.

Relive is a unique game. If you like bad games, this is sure to entertain your little masochistic self and for a lovely short 2 hours. But it's not fun. It's an absolute drudgery to complete. I'm giving Relive a 1/10.

reviewText:
A life threatening w̶e̶a̶p̶o̶n̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶s̶u̶r̶p̶a̶s̶s̶ ̶m̶e̶t̶a̶l̶ ̶g̶e̶a̶r̶ nano-machine storm is shutting down your station, you're trying to get to your boss and crew mates as fast as possible so you can safely EVAC, but you're stopped by you're greatest enemy.. The infirmary AI who can't understand what's happening, so it cuts off half the station from access, forcing you to retake the BLS exam so you can get an access card to open a door it's locked.

Yes, you heard right, let me reiterate.
You're stopped in a life threatening situation to take a course and exam on CPR and defib because the AI cuts off all your access and ability to provide help and medical assistance to your friends. You must complete the exam with 100%, or you're forced to take it over again while your friends slowly die and suffer horrible deaths...

I can nitpick at the plotholes all day, it's kind of fun, actually, but it has a good message, and solid gameplay/puzzle mechanics, although I do admit I didn't understand at points why I was doing certain things(SPOILER AHEAD: like jamming a pipewrench in a valve so it doesn't emergency shut-off even though you're constantly being lectured about safety. what? END SPOILERS)

The puzzles are fun, and the gameplay is smooth. The only thing that bothered me was the constant beeping whenever you hovered your icon over items, and the lack of ambient noise/sound effects.

10/10 would fail the exam by 1 point and let my friends suffer and die a cold, exhausting death on a desolate planet again.

reviewText:
While trying to make this game a bit more fun by including puzzles and involving some critical thinking (what little you would need, mostly to find the secrets ), it lacks the basic information about it's main purpose. Since I am from the USA, I do have my guidelines to go by and while researching for what the EU's version was....I wasn't able to find much. However, I believe the standards are the same. With that in mind, I'll break this down into 2 reviews.


CPR:
1) The way the game describes to check to see if they're awake, by shaking them, especially where you had to do it on an a player" in the game
date: could have killed them from trauma to the spinal cord. Common practice is to slap hard on the shoulds
recommended: not shake them.\n\n2) Head-tilt chin-lift technique doesn't leave the mouth open
hoursPlayed: because you're literally pressing up on the jaw. Should be a step to open it and see if they just choked (doing CPR on a person who just passed out from isn't harmful but you should be checking to make sure that you're doing the right thing).\n\n3) Many reasons why people don't do CPR is because the "rescue breaths"
voteText: which aren't necessarily needed and not as important as keeping the blood flowing to the brain and heart. This information should have been included also. As with rescue breaths
helpfulPercent: you're to keep about 100 beats per minute and then 120 without the breaths.\n\n4) It should have been explained better about the AED
votesHelpful: and how you won't ALWAYS shock a person and should continue CPR inbetween the readings. It should also explain what the purpose of the AED is. Movies and games (including this one) make it seem that when a person's heart stops
votesTotal: you just need to shock them to bring them back to life. Which isn't true for most cases. Unless they are in ventricular fibrillation (v-fib) or (in some AEDs) ventricular tachycardia (v-tach)
votesFunny: the AED won't shock. It should also explain to follow the vocal instructions of the AED and also the pads for both placement and when to do things. Also
commentsCount: if someone else brought it to you
column16: then you should ask them to set it up while continuing CPR. By this game
column18: you're supposed to waste time putting it together
column19: taking off the clothes (something else not 100% needed
column20:
just access to skin). and applying the pads. One person can do that while another person does compressions. The game itself says 3-5 minutes without oxygen and the brain starts to die. An unskilled person will take 5+ minutes to setup the AED.



Game itself:
1)   Ignoring the CPR faults

reviewText:
I loved the concept behind this game, but the execution was a little lacking. 70%

PROS
1. You learn CPR (I assume. I'm not medically trained, but to my novice self, this seemed like an accurate depiction)
2. Interesting art style
3. Cheery AI helpers!
4. It actually had a plot and gameplay outside the CPR training

CONS
1. The CPR learning section is kind of dull. It's not as interactive as it should be. I know clicking 30 times in a row might get annoying, but hey, it's more interactive.
2. Interesting" art style. Some of the characters looked a tad creepy.
3. The robots didn't nearly have enough impact as they should have. When faced with the prospect (and related achievement) of losing my AI helper
date: I was only mildly distraught. I should be bawling at this point. Probably what might help is getting some voice work for this game. If I could hear the tinge of sadness creep in to its normally chipper tone
recommended: that'd be more impactful. And while I'm at it
hoursPlayed: all the humans could stand to gain voices
voteText: too. And environment sound effects. And... we'll just call it here before I completely derail this review.\n4. The plot was kind of thin. The robots seem to insinuate that these nanobots were growing or evolving somehow
helpfulPercent: but that never is really resolved. Also
votesHelpful: apparently the doctor just randomly has a crush on Mike that never goes anywhere. I was certain that one of them was going to die to get us off this station
votesTotal: but nothing nearly so dramatic happens. Also
votesFunny: gameplay is pretty slow as a whole. A time element while you're racing to save your buddies (for example) would have been a good addition.\n\nOverall
commentsCount: I would recommend this game. However
column16: my approval is less about the game itself and more about the concept and the potential it holds. Perhaps we could get a sequel in the future where you learn not only CPR but other medical techniques and apply it in a more combat or action-oriented setting while the gung-ho robots and solemn team members actually speak audibly to you. That

reviewText:
An interesting adventure game which takes place in a research station on Mars, which has been breached by a nanite storm that threatens to destroy it. In this game you play as one of the crew members of said station, who needs to reunite with his fellow crew members and escape the station before it's destroyed.

What's interesting about this game isn't its depth or complexity; gameplay is quite simple, and follows the structure of traditional point-and-click adventures (where you look for different objects in order to progress and such), only that it's placed in a first person view; what's interesting is that a main point of this game is teaching the player basic CPR techniques, and I'd say it does a good job at that. It might not be the best way to learn it, but it does a good job of increasing awareness on how to act in situations that might require the use of CPR.

Other than that, the game is pretty short. It's still a good game, in my opinion, so I recommend it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
OK, Am Gonna Be Blunt and Say if this Game Wasn't For Free I Wouldn't Have Recommended it to Anyone, But Considering that it is for free you might wanna give it a free pass and try it, It's Not a Bad Experience Considering that the Developer's Main Objective is to Show You how To Perform CPR, I Thought that was the only Thing to do (You Jump from One Patient To Another) but there was a decent amount of Gameplay involved which made the game feel well balanced, Although i did enjoy the gameplay, there was a couple of issues That made the experience falter for a bit. First issue is that i had minor frustrations at first with the hacking puzzle ,which is also a minigame, but it didn't last for long because of the second gameplay issue and it's that i completed this game within 2 hours.....

*Pros:
-It's Free
-It Has Decent Visuals
-Overall Gameplay is Well Balanced
-Mars Space Station Setting is Good

*Cons:
-Short Story
-Hacking Puzzle/minigame

This is a relativly short game and you will learn a skill that can be usefull in real life in this game. Have Fun and Play Fair :)

reviewText:
Product received for free

This Game is A Great Game, It's a Si-Fi Finder Game that has CPR in it.

The Story and the gameplay is something that has a Very interesting concept with a point-and-click-free-roam-finder but with a concept of CPR mixed with it, surprisingly The CPR aspect Is very similar to an actual real CPR course, you could show this to a class learning about CPR and it would be remotely the same but with a Si-fi Mixed to it, and it would be very intresting to play and to see the way you would play it but I do recommend this Game.

I have taken a CPR class and passed, and the games, CPR is Very Very the same but keeping it Si-Fi

The Acvments are easy to get
